summary:
about me I am a PhD student in the Wellcome Trust doctoral training center for public health, economics, and decision science at the School of Health and Related Research (ScHARR), University of Sheffield.
My background is in clinical medicine and health sciences: I am a physician by training, and completed a doctoral degree in medicine at the Institute for Health Systems Research, University of Witten/Herdecke, Germany. I also hold a research masters degree in health sciences from Maastricht University, the Netherlands.
title: Paul P. Schneider

summary: Since population-based health state valuations are used to inform public policy, the valuation of health should not be understood as merely a statistical exercise, but as major instrument of democratic participation. This project explores how current methods can be improved, to better adhere to democratic principles.
title: Social tariffs and democratic choice

summary: This project is concerned with the interpersonal (in)comparability of health state utilities. Conceptual problems with the conventional method of health preference elicitation are identified, and a multi-step utility aggregation procedure is proposed, wich ensures that the preferences of all individuals have equal weight.
title: TTO utility rescaling

summary: A study of the social and geographic disparities in the access to and the participation in parkrun events in England.
title: parkrun participation

content:
Schneider PP1,2, van Gool CJAW3, Spreeuwenberg P4, Hooiveld M4, Donker GA4, Barnett DJ1, Paget J4.  1 Faculty of Health, Medicine and Life Sciences, Maastricht University; 2 School of Health and Related Research, University of Sheffield; 3 Nivel (Netherlands Institute of Health Service Research);
4 School CAPHRI, Maastricht University 

In the first stage of the project, I investigated whether Wikipedia page views were correlated with the incidence of influenza in several countries around the world.  Code and data repository[Deprecated!]  
Subsequently, I included Google search queries and used several statical learning techniques to estimate the incidence of influenza in Germany in near real time.  Conference poster for WEON 2018 A tutorial on digital epidemiology in R Data & code repository  
Finally, we piloted the method during the 2017-2018 influenza-like illness epidemic in the Netherlands.  Preprint: Schneider PP, van Gool CJAW, Spreeuwenberg P, Hooiveld M, Donker GA, Barnett DJ, Paget J. Preprint: Using digital epidemiology methods to monitor influenza-like illness in the Netherlands in real-time: the 2017-2018 season. bioRxiv. 2018. https://doi.org/10.1101/440867
 Publication: tbc
summary: A study of digital epidemiology methods to monitor influenza in near real-time, using online data and statistical learning.
title: Dutch flu trend

summary: Exploring the heterogeneity of (latent) cost trajectories in patients with advanced breast cancer in the Netherlands during the last year of life.
title: Cost trajectories

summary: A R tutorial on how to access your personal fitbit data and analyse your sleeping patterns.
title: fitbitR

summary: This study investigates the association between staffing (nurses and physicians) and the incidence of hospital-acquired pressure ulcers in acute care hospitals in Germany.
title: Staffing and the quality of care in German hospitals
